data.title: how do I find spark
data.text:
Faye Goldsmith Posted at 2018-3-29 00:45

yes done that, been to where it says 3 times and searched but can not find it..........not only did we get the error we also lost connection with it

The functions shows the last know location.

So when you disconnect, the location won't be updated.

Some questions:

1. Were you flying line of sight? (like, did you see the drone when it initiated RTH)

2. What was your RTH behavior set to?

3. Did you look at the flight logs to see if there were events like 'recording home point' etc.

It might be best to share the flight log here.

So other users can take a look at what the Drone said during the flight. This are the co ordinates it has given us -38.358009, 144.925353

Yes it was in Line of Sight when it decided to fly.........flew up quickly, wouldn't let us gain control. It had said home was home but it told us it was going to a place that it called home earlier in the day. Then we got the error.

Thanks for trying to help us

Faye Goldsmith Posted at 2018-3-29 02:18

This are the co ordinates it has given us -38.358009, 144.925353

Yes it was in Line of Sight when it decided to fly.........flew up quickly, wouldn't let us gain control. It had said home was home but it told us it was going to a place that it called home earlier in the day. Then we got the error.

>> It had said home was home but it told us it was going to a place that it called home earlier in the day. Then we got the error.<<

A thought which I have in mind for quiet some time:

How far away is the older RTH Point from the location you lost contact?

Could the Spark get there with the battery?

The last known location, is that between point of "RTH" kicked in and the older RTH-Point?

If yes, extend that line, calculate the rest flight time with a RTH Speed of 38 kph and try to find it further down to this older RTH location.

Do you remember the Starting/RTH point in question?

And keep in mind, on 10% battery, it will launch auto landing. So battery life to calculate is rest%age-10!

apcyberax Posted at 2018-3-29 05:22

the log shows it never recorded the RTH when you took off so it had no home point to return to

I noticed that too. Not sure what will happen when it did not record RTH.

My best guess is that it will fall back to the latest homepoint.

But I'm not sure if that makes sense judging by the observation from the pilot when it flew away.

Montfrooij Posted at 2018-3-29 05:49

I noticed that too. Not sure what will happen when it did not record RTH.

My best guess is that it will fall back to the latest homepoint.

But I'm not sure if that makes sense judging by the observation from the pilot when it flew away.

The question is, if the pilot had a homepoint, some time before, in the direction the spark took off!

My thought about most "fly aways" is:

Spark "sees" spontaniously a former homepoint "far away" as the actual one, reacts and off it goes.

S-e-ven Posted at 2018-3-29 06:14

The question is, if the pilot had a homepoint, some time before, in the direction the spark took off!

My thought about most "fly aways" is:

Spark "sees" spontaniously a former homepoint "far away" as the actual one, reacts and off it goes.

The log does not show any recording of the homepoint.

Now I don't know if that is normal behavior (I believe my MP said 'recording homepoint' on takeoff), but I have not been looking at my flight logs. @Faye Goldsmith, here's what your flight log tells me:

After 2m 20s into your flight, your Spark automatically switched to ATTI mode due to a yaw errror (compass related issue). Issues like that are normally caused by taking off near a source of magetic metal (like a concrete sidewalk).

Once in ATTI mode, the Spark started drifting with the wind since it was not able to use the GPS data to hold its position.

The attempt to initiate RTH failed since the Spark was flying in ATTI mode at that time. The Spark cannot automatically return home when flying in ATTI mode since it's not able to use the GPS data to locate the home point.

At the end of the flight log, the Spark was flying at an altitude of 120 feet (above the takeoff point) and drifting away with the wind at about 8.5 MPH (3.8 m/s).

Assuming the remote controller disconnected from the Spark at the end of your flight log, the Spark would have attempted to RTH 3 seconds after that point. Since your Spark was flying in ATTI mode, it would have auto landed at its current location instead of attempting to return home. Normally, that location would be close to the last coordinates marked in the flight log. However, since the wind was blowing your Spark away, it would have been drifting as it was auto landing.

Since your Spark was fairly low to the ground and moving slowly, it should be close to the last location in your flight log (-38.35693254,144.9216826). Look for it in the area boxed off in yellow here:

Location.jpg (0 Bytes, Down times: 34)

Download attach

2018-3-29 Upload

Montfrooij Posted at 2018-3-29 05:49

I noticed that too. Not sure what will happen when it did not record RTH.

My best guess is that it will fall back to the latest homepoint.

But I'm not sure if that makes sense judging by the observation from the pilot when it flew away.

Agree more likely the RTG failed message was the key that it had no home point. At that point, if the GPS was off and the craft was malfunctioning it would have drifted itself. Hi

We really do appreciate your help, have been this morning to the area you have showed us but noone has seen it. Last video contact we had had it go over a freeway but what you show us shows it is this side of freeway. Find my drone also says otherside of freeway. Is it possible for it to have flown back to this side? I have no idea how to find the coordinates like you guys do so can't see if they were recorded early in the flight log.

msinger Posted at 2018-3-29 17:19

Is there a second flight log file from that flight? The log you uploaded doesn't show your drone anywhere near the highway.

Also, can you post the video you're referring to?

sorry only the one flight log. Camera was on but wasn't recording so no video sorry. Went to the coordinates this morning, and just now got google maps to take me for a walk, which told me I was there corner of our street, even tho the pin was showing in leash free park, went there (again) stood right were pin is but no drone, ground or trees. Losing hope

Faye Goldsmith Posted at 2018-3-29 18:40

sorry only the one flight log. Camera was on but wasn't recording so no video sorry. Went to the coordinates this morning, and just now got google maps to take me for a walk, which told me I was there corner of our street, even tho the pin was showing in leash free park, went there (again) stood right were pin is but no drone, ground or trees. Losing hope

Really sorry for this. If there is a need, please contact our support for a further help.
